item.title: Actors with CMSIS OS in Cpp
item.description: The actor library defines the actor abstraction with mailboxes and concrete implementation for various target platforms. The CMSIS-RTOS v2 platform provides an actor implementation for all realtime kernels supporting the CMSIS API. The API is under the stewardship of ARM company. Any kernel with a CMSIS-RTOS v2 compatible layer is eligible. STM provides the CMSIS integration with freeRTOS for all STM32 microcontrollers. Library The library defines key abstractions as abstract classes [1] [2].

item.title: Bus Sensors and Actuators
item.description: Your embedded system has a set of sensors and actors. Some sensors and actors are connected to a bus. Typical buses are CAN bus, Serial Peripherical Interface, Ethernet, Bluetooth, or I2C standards. The bus is a shared medium used to communicate with a set of external active or passive components. Which design rules shall you follow when designing sensors and actors using a bus architecture? Do you need to consider threading design?

item.title: Sensors and Actuators
item.description: Embedded design maps domain abstractions to the underlying hardware. A temperature sensor is a domain abstraction of a physical hardware temperature sensor. A valve is a domain abstraction of a physical hardware valve. A physical valve can be a simple opened-closed device, or a proportional device. The microcontroller board reads the temperature sensor through an I2C or SPI bus. It controls the valve through a GPIO, a PWM or a CAN bus controller.
